annotation.summary: This paragraph is a table of contents excerpt from a tabletop role-playing game rulebook, listing major sections such as character creation, ancestries, backgrounds, classes, skills, and feats.

This section appears to be a table of contents listing various categories of equipment and related game mechanics, including armor, weapons, upgrades, ammunition, grenades, magic items, augmentations, and spells. It also references sections on gameplay rules, conditions, glossary, and character sheets.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this text is an index rather than a rules description.
annotation.prerequisites: None; this section serves as a navigational reference for the rulebook.

annotation.summary: A list of reference sections typically found at the end of a tabletop role-playing game rulebook, including explanations of conditions, a glossary and index for quick lookup, and a character sheet for recording player information.
Starfinder is a science-fantasy tabletop RPG where players create characters who explore a galaxy filled with magic, technology, and alien cultures, shaping the story through their decisions.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this paragraph provides an overview of the game rather than mechanical details.
annotation.prerequisites: None; this serves as an introduction to the game concept.

annotation.summary: Describes the collaborative storytelling nature of a roleplaying game, where the Game Master presents challenges and players control characters who attempt to overcome them through various types of conflicts and interactions.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section provides narrative context rather than mechanical actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; serves as an introductory explanation of the game's structure.

annotation.summary: The paragraph describes the basic structure of a tabletop role-playing game, explaining the roles of the Game Master (GM) and players, how they collaboratively tell a story, and how dice rolls introduce chance to determine success or failure of actions.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; general narrative flow without defined turn or action structure.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires a group of 4–7 players, one acting as the Game Master.

annotation.summary: Describes how Starfinder sessions can vary in length from single one-shot adventures to long-running campaigns, emphasizing flexibility and enjoyment for both GM and players.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section discusses session structure, not in-game actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies to all players and GMs starting a game.

annotation.summary: Describes that a game session may focus heavily on action, including combat, technical challenges, and mission objectives.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified in this paragraph.
annotation.prerequisites: None mentioned.

annotation.summary: The paragraph emphasizes that Starfinder is a flexible game meant for collaborative storytelling and enjoyment. Players and GMs are encouraged to modify or ignore rules that hinder fun, as long as the group agrees.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this passage describes game philosophy rather than mechanical actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies universally to all players and game masters.

annotation.summary: The paragraph describes the wide range of possible adventures in a sci-fi TTRPG, from labor organization and espionage to negotiation and exploration, emphasizing that the tone and focus of the game are determined collaboratively by the players and game master.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section discusses narrative scope rather than mechanical actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies to all players and game types.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that all participants, including the Game Master, are players, though 'player' typically refers to non-GM participants. Before play begins, players create characters with defined histories, personalities, and game statistics. The GM may impose limits on character creation, but these should be discussed beforehand to ensure everyone can make engaging characters. Ultimately, character concepts are guided by player imagination within the GM’s boundaries.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section describes preparation before gameplay rather than in-game actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Players must collaborate with the GM to establish character concepts and adhere to any agreed-upon creation limits.

annotation.summary: Players narrate their characters' actions and roll dice based on abilities, while the GM determines outcomes. Players may choose to act in character or describe actions narratively.
annotation.action_economy: Players take turns describing actions; GM resolves outcomes based on dice rolls.
annotation.prerequisites: Players must have characters with defined abilities and access to dice.

annotation.summary: The text advises newcomers to start as players to learn the rules and setting of the game.
annotation.prerequisites: None; intended for new players.

annotation.summary: Explains the dice notation used in Starfinder, detailing the types of dice (d4 through d20) and how to interpret expressions like '4d6' or 'd%'.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: Players must have access to standard polyhedral dice sets (d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, d20).

annotation.summary: The Game Master (GM) oversees the story, setting, and rule interpretation in the game, describing situations, reacting to player actions, and using the guidance from the Starfinder GM Core.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; describes a narrative role rather than an in-game action.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires familiarity with the Starfinder GM Core and understanding of general TTRPG structure.

annotation.summary: The paragraph emphasizes the importance of a social contract in tabletop roleplaying games, encouraging players and the GM to communicate expectations, discuss boundaries, and ensure that everyone feels comfortable and respected so all participants can enjoy the game together.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section concerns social guidelines rather than in-game actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies to all participants before and during play.

annotation.summary: Emphasizes that maintaining a fun and inclusive game environment is a shared responsibility among all players, not solely the Game Master.

Players and the GM require at least one set of polyhedral dice, typically including six-sided dice, which are commonly available at hobby stores or online. A sidebar provides more details on dice types and notation.
annotation.prerequisites: Access to at least one set of polyhedral dice.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that in Starfinder, players control player characters (PCs) while the Game Master controls nonplayer characters (NPCs) and monsters. PCs are the story's protagonists, whereas NPCs and monsters serve supporting or opposing roles, though all share certain game traits.
Level represents a creature’s overall power and capability, serving as a key measure of progression and challenge in the game. Player characters typically begin at level 1.

Characters gain experience points (XP) by completing adventures and defeating foes. Every 1,000 XP increases their level, granting new abilities and allowing them to face progressively greater challenges, from minor creatures at 1st level to godlike foes at 20th level.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this describes long-term progression rather than in-combat actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must earn 1,000 XP to advance to the next level.

annotation.summary: This section explains that characters possess six core attributes—Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma—which define their natural abilities and influence most other statistics. Attribute modifiers typically range from –5 to +5 for ordinary beings, with higher-level characters capable of exceeding this range. Positive modifiers improve success chances on related tasks, while negative ones reduce them.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section describes character statistics rather than actions or turn structure.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies to all characters at creation.

annotation.summary: Character creation involves selecting ancestry, background, and class, which together define a player character's heritage, upbringing, and primary abilities.
annotation.prerequisites: None; these are initial choices made during character creation.

annotation.summary: Player characters gain feats—special abilities chosen at creation and as they level up. Each feat has a type indicating its source and a theme describing its focus. Characters also possess skills that represent their proficiency in various practical tasks such as healing, computing, and piloting.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section describes character options rather than actions in play.
annotation.prerequisites: None explicitly stated; feats and skills are chosen based on character progression and available options.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that while players make narrative choices for their characters in Starfinder, the outcomes of those actions are determined by the game's rules, character abilities, player decisions, and dice rolls.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section describes narrative and rule interaction rather than specific actions or turns.
annotation.prerequisites: None; this is an introductory explanation of how player decisions and game mechanics interact.

annotation.summary: The Game Master (GM) establishes the main premise and background for adventures, while player-created character histories and personalities also influence the story once play begins.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable
annotation.prerequisites: Requires a designated Game Master and player characters with defined backgrounds.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that in Starfinder, the setting itself—through hazards, traps, and treasures—can influence gameplay much like characters and monsters. Environmental hazards and magic items are assigned levels to represent their danger or power, helping integrate them mechanically into the game.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section describes narrative and mechanical context rather than specific actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; this is general guidance for understanding how non-character elements function in the game.

annotation.summary: Players take turns describing their characters' actions while the GM narrates outcomes, environments, and events. The group collaboratively builds the story, with success determined by player choices and dice rolls.
annotation.action_economy: Players act in turns, each describing one or more character actions before the GM resolves outcomes.
annotation.prerequisites: A group of players including a GM; understanding of turn structure and dice mechanics.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that Starfinder gameplay operates in three modes—exploration, encounter, and downtime—each defining the pacing and focus of the story. Exploration involves discovery and interaction, encounters involve combat or conflict, and downtime covers rest and training. Play transitions between these modes as the story progresses.
annotation.action_economy: Not directly applicable; each mode has its own pacing and structure rather than a shared action economy.
annotation.prerequisites: None; these modes are fundamental to all Starfinder gameplay.

annotation.summary: When a character faces an uncertain or risky situation, they make a check by rolling a d20 and adding a relevant attribute modifier to determine success or failure.
annotation.action_economy: Varies; typically part of an action or task resolution during play.
annotation.prerequisites: A situation with an uncertain outcome requiring a relevant attribute or skill.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains how to determine the outcome of a check by comparing the rolled result to a target number called the Difficulty Class (DC). Meeting or exceeding the DC results in success, while falling short results in failure. Exceeding the DC by 10 or more is a critical success, and failing by 10 or more is a critical failure. Rolling a natural 20 often counts as a critical success, and rolling a natural 1 often counts as a critical failure.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this rule governs outcome resolution, not actions per turn.
annotation.prerequisites: A roll must be made and a Difficulty Class (DC) must be established by the GM.

annotation.summary: If a check does not specify a unique outcome for a critical success or failure, treat those results as normal successes or failures.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: none

annotation.summary: The paragraph illustrates how a Piloting skill check works during starship navigation. A player attempts a risky maneuver through an asteroid field, rolls a d20, adds their skill modifier, and compares the total to the GM’s set DC. The outcome—critical success, success, failure, or critical failure—determines how well the ship navigates the hazard.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; represents a narrative or skill check outside of combat rounds.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have access to the Piloting skill to attempt the check.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that checks are a core mechanic used to determine task outcomes. A roll of the die is combined with a modifier, which includes an attribute modifier and a proficiency bonus, and may be further adjusted by other situational factors like equipment, spells, or abilities.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; describes general resolution mechanics rather than specific actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies universally to all characters and situations involving checks.

annotation.summary: Proficiency measures a character's skill level in a task, divided into five ranks—untrained, trained, expert, master, and legendary—each providing a different proficiency bonus. Untrained characters receive no bonus and rely only on their attribute modifier.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; proficiency affects checks and rolls rather than actions per turn.
annotation.prerequisites: None; all characters begin with proficiency ranks assigned by their class or background.

annotation.summary: Proficiency ranks—trained, expert, master, and legendary—add a bonus equal to the character’s level plus a rank-based modifier (2, 4, 6, or 8). These ranks influence most game statistics.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: character must have a proficiency rank in the relevant skill or statistic

annotation.summary: Describes the exploration phase of gameplay, where characters freely interact with the environment, travel, and respond to narrative prompts without strict turn structure.
annotation.action_economy: Not structured; actions occur organically based on player decisions and narrative flow.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies to all characters during exploration.

annotation.summary: The text gives examples of exploration scenarios, such as a crowded gravtrain.

The paragraph provides examples of exploration activities, including traveling by enercopter, identifying threats like a marauding kyokor, predicting its movements, and negotiating with locals to protect a city.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; these are narrative or downtime exploration actions rather than combat actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None explicitly stated; assumes characters are capable of travel, observation, and negotiation.

annotation.summary: The GM prompts players to describe their characters' actions during exploration, which can influence advantages or circumstances when combat begins.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; focuses on narrative actions during exploration rather than turn-based mechanics.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies generally during exploration phases.

annotation.summary: Describes encounters in Starfinder as structured challenges that often involve combat but can also cover time-sensitive or high-stakes situations like chases, hazards, or tense social interactions.
annotation.action_economy: Varies by encounter type; typically involves turn-based actions during combat or structured time segments in other challenges.
annotation.prerequisites: Occurs when a simple skill check cannot resolve a challenge or when characters face direct opposition or time pressure.

annotation.summary: Encounters are structured sequences where participants act in initiative order over rounds of about six seconds. Each participant takes a turn per round and can use up to three actions on their turn. Simple tasks cost one action, while more complex activities, such as spellcasting, may require multiple actions.
annotation.prerequisites: An encounter must be initiated and initiative order established before turns and actions are taken.

annotation.summary: Free actions do not consume any of the three actions available on a character's turn. Each character also has one reaction per round, which can be used outside their turn in response to specific triggers if they possess an ability that grants such a reaction.

action_economy.free_actions: Unlimited, do not count toward the three actions per turn.
action_economy.reactions: One per round, usable outside your turn when triggered by specific events.

annotation.prerequisites: A character must have an ability or feat that grants a reaction option.

annotation.summary: The Strike action allows a creature to attack another by making an attack roll against the target's Armor Class (AC). The roll includes modifiers from proficiency, attributes, and situational bonuses or penalties. If the roll meets or exceeds the target's AC, the attack hits and deals damage; a critical success doubles the damage.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action
annotation.prerequisites: Must be in a situation where attacking a target is possible and have a valid means of attack (weapon, spell, or natural attack).

annotation.summary: When making multiple Strike actions in a turn, each additional attack suffers an increasing penalty to accuracy: –5 on the second attack and –10 on the third. The penalty resets at the end of the turn and can be reduced by certain abilities or effects.
annotation.action_economy: Multiple Strike actions within a single turn; each additional Strike applies a cumulative penalty.
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to perform a Strike action.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains saving throws, which are checks made to resist harmful effects from spells or abilities. There are three types: Fortitude (resisting physical harm or disease), Reflex (dodging area effects), and Will (defending against mental assaults). Success reduces harm, and a critical success avoids it entirely.
annotation.action_economy: Saving throws are reactive and occur outside a character's normal turn when targeted by an effect.
annotation.prerequisites: Triggered when a character is affected by a spell or ability that calls for a saving throw.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that attacks, spells, hazards, and special abilities can deal damage or impose conditions on creatures. Damage reduces Hit Points, and reaching 0 HP causes unconsciousness or death. Conditions temporarily or permanently hinder a creature’s actions and may require powerful means to remove.
annotation.action_economy: Conditions can restrict available actions or impose penalties during combat turns.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies generally to all creatures and combat situations.

annotation.summary: The paragraph describes the concept of downtime in Starfinder, a period when player characters engage in non-adventuring activities such as recovering, crafting, researching, retraining, or earning credits. It allows time to pass quickly while characters pursue long-term goals or personal development through roleplay and skill checks.
annotation.action_economy: Occurs outside of combat and regular adventuring; represents days or weeks of in-game time rather than discrete actions or turns.
annotation.prerequisites: None; all characters can participate in downtime, though certain activities may require specific skills or resources.

annotation.summary: Each creature receives three actions per turn in an encounter, which can be used for attacking, moving, interacting with objects, or using special abilities. Common actions are detailed in Chapter 8.
annotation.action_economy: Three actions per turn
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must be participating in an encounter

annotation.summary: An ancestry defines a character's origin and determines their initial traits such as Hit Points, languages, senses, Speed, and available ancestry feats.
Armor Class (AC) measures how difficult it is to successfully hit and damage a creature, functioning as the target number for attack rolls.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: creature must exist within the game system and have an assigned Armor Class value

annotation.summary: Describes how creatures perform attacks, primarily through Strikes with weapons, unarmed attacks, or spells.
annotation.action_economy: Requires an attack action, typically a single action to perform a Strike or similar attack.
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must be capable of making an attack or using a spell that targets another creature.

annotation.summary: The paragraph introduces six core attributes—Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma—that define a creature’s innate abilities and training, with detailed explanations provided later in the chapter.
Backgrounds describe a character’s life before adventuring and provide a feat along with one or more trained skills.
annotation.prerequisites: Character creation stage

annotation.summary: Explains how bonuses and penalties of the same type do not stack; only the highest bonus and worst penalty apply to checks and statistics.
Describes how to resolve uncertain actions by rolling a 20-sided die and adding the relevant proficiency bonus to determine success.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; applies generally to any uncertain action.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have a relevant proficiency to add its bonus to the roll.

annotation.summary: A class defines a character’s adventuring role, determining their proficiencies, hit points gained per level, and available class feats.
Defines a condition as an ongoing effect that modifies a character's actions or statistics, with detailed rules available in the Conditions Appendix.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; describes persistent effects rather than actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies generally to all characters and effects.

annotation.summary: Characters start the game with 150 credits, which serve as the standard currency for purchasing equipment.
Feats are special abilities chosen for a character based on their ancestry, background, class, or training, granting new actions or improving existing ones.
annotation.action_economy: Varies; some feats provide new actions, others modify existing ones.
annotation.prerequisites: Dependent on ancestry, background, class, or skill training.

annotation.summary: The Game Master (GM) oversees the game, interprets rules, and narrates the story and world for the other players, using the Starfinder GM Core as the primary reference.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this describes a role, not an action.
annotation.prerequisites: Must serve as the Game Master and have access to the Starfinder GM Core.

annotation.summary: The paragraph introduces the Starfinder setting, describing the Pact Worlds system—an alliance of planets that once included the lost world Golarion—and notes that adventures often extend across the wider galaxy. It also references additional sources for more information.
Creatures roll initiative at the start of an encounter to determine the order of actions, with higher rolls acting earlier.
annotation.action_economy: Determines the sequence of turns but does not consume an action.
annotation.prerequisites: Encounter must begin; all creatures involved participate in the roll.

annotation.summary: Levels represent the relative power or danger of characters, creatures, hazards, and items. Player characters range from level 1 to 20, while other entities can range from –1 to 30. Item levels, typically 0 to 20, indicate their strength and appropriateness as treasure.
Perception represents a character's awareness and ability to notice hidden details or react quickly, influencing initiative in combat.
annotation.action_economy: Passive; may influence initiative order in combat.
annotation.prerequisites: None; all characters have a Perception score.

annotation.summary: Describes the proficiency system, which measures a character's skill level in various tasks using five ranks that grant increasing bonuses to key statistics.
annotation.action_economy: None
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains how rarity categorizes game elements like equipment, spells, and feats based on how frequently they appear in the game world. Common items are freely available, uncommon ones require special background or training, rare ones are GM-awarded, and unique ones are one-of-a-kind. The GM can modify rarity to fit the story.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: None; rarity determines availability rather than requiring specific actions or abilities.

annotation.summary: Explains that describing or speaking as a character is called roleplaying, and doing so means the player is 'in character.'
A round is a unit of time in an encounter where every participant takes their turn, lasting about six seconds in the game world.
annotation.action_economy: Defines the duration in which all participants act once per round.
annotation.prerequisites: Occurs during an encounter or combat scenario.

annotation.summary: A saving throw is an automatic roll made to resist or reduce a harmful effect. It requires no action or reaction, and the creature affected rolls against a DC set by the source of the effect.
annotation.action_economy: No action or reaction required
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must be subject to a harmful or dangerous effect

annotation.summary: Skills measure a creature's learned abilities for specific tasks. Characters gain training in certain skills from their background and class. Each skill outlines what can be done untrained and what requires training.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified
annotation.prerequisites: Some skill uses require training; others can be attempted untrained.

annotation.summary: Defines speed as the distance a character can move with one action, measured in feet.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: Spells are magical effects produced through incantations and gestures. Casting typically requires two actions, and each spell defines its targets, casting requirements, effects, and resistance methods. Class-specific spellcasting details are found in the class descriptions, while individual spells are listed separately.
annotation.action_economy: Usually requires two actions to cast a spell.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have a class or ability that grants spellcasting.

annotation.summary: Spells are organized by ranks from 1st to 10th, representing their power level, and both characters and monsters have limits on how many spells of each rank they can cast.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to cast spells of the appropriate rank

annotation.summary: Traits are keywords that provide extra context about a rules element, such as its ancestry, rarity, or how it interacts with other game mechanics.
The book's traits are compiled and explained in the Glossary and Index starting on page 442.
Each creature acts in initiative order, taking one turn per round and usually having up to three actions to spend during that turn.
annotation.action_economy: Each creature has up to three actions to use on its turn.
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must have an initiative position in the round.

annotation.summary: The crew pilots their ship through a hazardous debris field in the Drift. Zemir attempts a Piloting check to navigate the obstacles but rolls poorly, narrowly avoiding a crash while losing his intended course. Another crew member, Chk Chk, lightens the mood by sharing a poem about perseverance.
annotation.action_economy: One Piloting check action to navigate the debris field.
annotation.prerequisites: Access to a starship and proficiency or training in the Piloting skill.

annotation.summary: Zemir narrowly avoids a collision by reacting quickly at the last moment.
annotation.action_economy: reaction
annotation.prerequisites: The character must be aware of the impending collision.

annotation.summary: Quick Install allows a character to complete an Upgrade installation in 1 minute instead of the usual 10 minutes.
annotation.action_economy: 1 minute
annotation.prerequisites: Must have the Quick Install skill feat

annotation.summary: During a space mission, Dae exits the ship using a jetpack to rescue a wounded ysoki whose suit is damaged. After bringing the ysoki back to the airlock, Dae notices new blood smears, suggesting something has boarded the ship. The crew prepares for an imminent threat as scraping noises approach the bridge.

prerequisites.environment: space environment with airlock and zero gravity
conditions: crew must be suited for EVA

annotation.summary: The character named Chk Chk, played by Dustin, draws their weapon called a painglaive and verifies or reaffirms a mystical or emotional bond.
annotation.action_economy: Likely one action to draw the weapon; checking the bond may be a free or narrative action depending on system rules.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must possess a painglaive and have an established bond feature or ability.

annotation.summary: Two undead figures—a vesk and a human in damaged spacesuits—appear as an automatic door opens, prompting the players to roll for initiative.
annotation.action_economy: Initiative roll begins; combat round order is established.
annotation.prerequisites: Players must be present in the scene when the autodoor opens.

annotation.summary: The scene introduces undead or decaying foes, prompting the players to begin combat by rolling initiative.
annotation.action_economy: Combat begins; turn order is determined by initiative rolls.
annotation.prerequisites: Encounter with hostile creatures; players must be ready to engage in combat.

annotation.summary: During initiative, all participants roll Perception to determine turn order. The GM records results from highest to lowest, including hidden rolls for unseen NPCs. Some characters have special abilities that trigger upon rolling initiative.
annotation.action_economy: No actions are spent; this occurs before combat begins.
annotation.prerequisites: Participants must be in a situation requiring initiative, typically at the start of combat or a timed encounter.

annotation.summary: The character Dae creates a quantum field between themselves and an enemy, using their ability as a Solarian to attune as a free action when initiative is rolled. They choose graviton attunement and summon a solar weapon made of void energy.
annotation.action_economy: Free action (attune when rolling initiative)
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be a Solarian with the ability to attune and manifest a solar weapon

annotation.summary: Zemir uses one Focus Point to cast Warp Terrain, creating an area of difficult terrain filled with debris from an alternate reality, then uses his next action to attack a vesk with a laser pistol.
annotation.action_economy: Two actions: one to cast Warp Terrain (costs 1 Focus Point), one to make a ranged attack with a laser pistol.
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to cast Warp Terrain and possession of at least 1 Focus Point; equipped with a laser pistol.

annotation.summary: The text indicates the start of a turn where the speaker declares spending an action, likely initiating a move or ability.
annotation.action_economy: Uses 1 action at the start of the character's turn.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have at least 1 available action to spend.

annotation.summary: A partial sentence referencing taking an action, possibly related to maneuvering or completing a task involving an asteroid.
annotation.action_economy: mentions taking an action, but details are missing
annotation.prerequisites: none specified due to incomplete context

annotation.summary: Zemir uses his third action to take cover behind a rock within his quantum field, while an undead vesk retaliates by firing a void energy bolt at him.
annotation.action_economy: Third action used to Take Cover
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have an available action and a nearby object or terrain feature to take cover behind.

annotation.summary: The character uses their third action to take cover behind an object or terrain feature, improving their defenses against attacks.
annotation.action_economy: one action (third action in the turn)
annotation.prerequisites: There must be an object or feature nearby that provides cover.

annotation.summary: Thurston's first attack misses Zemir due to a cover bonus, but the second attack hits, dealing 6 void damage. The driftdead then moves toward Obozaya but cannot reach her because difficult terrain halves its movement speed.
annotation.action_economy: Two ranged attacks followed by a move action.
annotation.prerequisites: Target within range; awareness of cover bonuses and terrain effects.

annotation.summary: Dustin's character, Chk Chk, uses two actions to cast a spell called 'vibe check' that transmits an angry poem telepathically, then uses another ability, Transfer Vitality, to heal an ally named Zemir for 7 Hit Points.
annotation.action_economy: Two actions to cast 'vibe check'; additional action or effect to use 'Transfer Vitality'.
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to cast spells and access to the 'Transfer Vitality' ability or spell.

annotation.summary: A driftdead fails a Will saving throw against a spell and is compelled to attack the nearest creature, striking its ally for 4 damage.
annotation.action_economy: The driftdead must use its next action to attack the nearest creature.
annotation.prerequisites: A spell or effect that forces a Will saving throw against a spell DC.

annotation.summary: A walking corpse attacks a character named Chk Chk, making a claw attack with an attack roll of 23.
annotation.action_economy: Standard action or single attack (GM narration of enemy turn)
annotation.prerequisites: Encounter in progress; walking corpse within melee range of Chk Chk

annotation.summary: The undead creature directs its hostility toward the player character, preparing to attack.
annotation.action_economy: The creature uses its turn to target and attack the player.
annotation.prerequisites: The walking corpse must be present and aware of the player character.

annotation.summary: Dae uses the Stellar Rush ability to charge down the hall into the bridge, generating black lightning that pulls nearby enemies toward her as she passes.
annotation.action_economy: Standard action or movement-based ability (used on Dae's turn)
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have access to the Stellar Rush ability or similar power

annotation.summary: Stellar Rush is a Solarian feat allowing the character to Stride twice with a +10 circumstance bonus to speed. After moving, all enemies within 15 feet must make a Fortitude save against the user's Class DC (21 in the example) or be pulled adjacent. The feat has the cycle trait, shifting the user's attunement to photon after completion.
annotation.action_economy: Two Strides as part of a single feat action
annotation.prerequisites: Solarian class; access to the Stellar Rush feat

annotation.summary: Dae ignites her black battle ribbon with solar energy, performs a dramatic spinning attack against a vesk, and rolls a 26 on her attack roll while ensuring the action is captured on camera.
annotation.action_economy: Standard action (attack)
annotation.prerequisites: Character must possess a solar or energy-based weapon or ability; target must be within melee range.

annotation.summary: The character Obozaya uses the ability 'Menacing Laughter' as their third action, which causes the enemy to become suppressed.
annotation.action_economy: third action
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have access to the 'Menacing Laughter' ability.

annotation.summary: Obozaya attempts an Intimidation check with a +11 modifier but fails with a roll of 1. Despite the failure, her attack still suppresses the driftdead, imposing a –1 circumstance penalty to its attack rolls and a –10-foot status penalty to its Speed until the start of her next turn.
annotation.action_economy: Standard action (Intimidation check as part of an attack)
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to make an Intimidation check and perform an attack that can suppress a target

annotation.summary: Describes the transition from the first to the second round of combat, maintaining the same initiative order and adding any new participants.
annotation.action_economy: No specific actions; indicates the start of a new round where all combatants act in initiative order.
annotation.prerequisites: Completion of the first round of combat.
